informal_statement:
Compute the sum of all the roots of
$(2x+3)(x-4)+(2x+3)(x-6)=0 $

$ \textbf{(A) } \frac{7}{2}\qquad \textbf{(B) } 4\qquad \textbf{(C) } 5\qquad \textbf{(D) } 7\qquad \textbf{(E) } 13 $ Show that it is \textbf{(A) }7/2.
informal_proof: We expand to get $2x^2-8x+3x-12+2x^2-12x+3x-18=0$ which is $4x^2-14x-30=0$ after combining like terms. Using the quadratic part of [[Vieta's Formulas]], we find the sum of the roots is $\frac{14}4 = \textbf{(A) }7/2$.
formal_statement:
theorem amc12a_2002_p1:
  fixes f::"complex \<Rightarrow> complex"
  assumes "\<forall> x. f x = (2 * x + 3) * (x - 4) + (2 * x + 3) * (x - 6)"
  shows "(\<Sum> y \<in> f -` {0}. y) = 7/2"
